server.name: redisctl
server.description: Redis Cloud, Enterprise, and Database management tools with full CRUD operations and Redis Stack module support

database.description: Direct Redis database connection tools including Redis Stack modules

subcategories.streams: Redis Streams for event sourcing and message queues

tools.name: database_ping
tools.summary: Ping Redis server to check connectivity
tools.description: Ping the Redis server to check connectivity and verify the connection is alive. Returns PONG if successful. Use this to test if Redis is reachable.

tools.name: database_info
tools.description: Get comprehensive server information using the INFO command. Can specify a section like 'server', 'memory', 'stats', 'replication', 'cpu', 'cluster', 'keyspace', etc.

tools.name: database_dbsize
tools.summary: Get number of keys in database
tools.description: Returns the total number of keys in the currently selected database (DBSIZE command). Use this to find out how many keys exist.

tools.name: database_scan
tools.description: Non-blocking scan of keys matching a glob pattern. Returns up to 'count' keys. Safe alternative to KEYS command for production use.

tools.name: database_type
tools.description: Returns the data type of a key: string, list, set, zset (sorted set), hash, stream, or none if key doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_exists
tools.description: Check if a key exists in the database. Returns 1 if exists, 0 if not.

tools.name: database_ttl
tools.description: Get the time-to-live of a key in seconds. Returns -1 if no expiration set, -2 if key doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_memory_usage
tools.description: Get the memory usage of a key in bytes using MEMORY USAGE command. Useful for understanding memory consumption.

tools.name: database_rename
tools.description: Atomically renames a key to a new name. If the new key already exists, it will be overwritten. Returns an error if the source key doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_del
tools.description: Removes keys and their associated values from the database. Returns the number of keys that were actually deleted. Use this to remove data or clean up expired/unused keys.

tools.name: database_expire
tools.description: Set a key's expiration time in seconds. After the timeout, the key will be automatically deleted. Returns true if the timeout was set, false if the key doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_persist
tools.description: Makes the key persistent (removes expiration). Returns true if the timeout was removed, false if the key doesn't exist or has no timeout.

tools.name: database_get
tools.description: Get the value of a string key using the GET command. Only works for string type keys.

tools.name: database_set
tools.description: Set a string value. Creates or overwrites the key. Supports optional expiration (ex for seconds, px for milliseconds) and conditional set (nx: only if not exists, xx: only if exists).

tools.name: database_incr
tools.description: Increment a key's integer value by 1. If the key doesn't exist, it's created with value 0 before incrementing. Use this for counters, rate limiters, or sequence generators.

tools.name: database_decr
tools.description: Decrement a key's integer value by 1. If the key doesn't exist, it's created with value 0 before decrementing. Use this for countdown counters or decrementing stock levels.

tools.name: database_incrby
tools.description: Increment a key's integer value by a specific amount. Use negative increment to decrement. Perfect for counters with custom increments like adding points or adjusting balances.

tools.name: database_hgetall
tools.summary: Get all hash fields and values
tools.description: Get all fields and values of a hash using HGETALL command. Perfect for reading user profiles, objects, or any key-value structured data stored in a hash.

tools.name: database_hget
tools.description: Get a specific field from a hash. Returns null if the field or hash doesn't exist. Use this when you only need one field instead of fetching all fields with HGETALL.

tools.name: database_hlen
tools.description: Get the number of fields in a hash using HLEN command.

tools.name: database_hset
tools.description: Set a field in a hash. Creates the hash if it doesn't exist. Returns 1 if the field is new, 0 if updated. Use hashes to store objects like user profiles, product details, or configuration.

tools.name: database_hset_multiple
tools.description: Set multiple fields in a hash at once. More efficient than multiple HSET calls. Creates the hash if it doesn't exist. Use this to create or update entire objects in one operation.

tools.name: database_hdel
tools.description: Delete one or more fields from a hash. Returns the number of fields that were removed. Use this to remove specific properties from an object without deleting the entire hash.

tools.name: database_lrange
tools.description: Get a range of elements from a list. Use start=0, stop=-1 to get all elements. Great for reading event logs, queues, or message lists.

tools.name: database_lindex
tools.description: Get an element from a list by index. Index is 0-based; negative indices count from the end (-1 is the last element). Returns null if the index is out of range.

tools.name: database_llen
tools.description: Get the number of elements in a list using LLEN command.

tools.name: database_lpush
tools.description: Push values to the left (head) of a list. Creates the list if it doesn't exist. Values are inserted at the head. Use this for implementing stacks (LIFO) or adding items to the front of a queue.

tools.name: database_rpush
tools.description: Push values to the right (tail) of a list. Creates the list if it doesn't exist. Values are appended to the end in order. Use this for implementing queues (FIFO), event logs, or message lists.

tools.name: database_lpop
tools.description: Pop and return a value from the left (head) of a list. Removes and returns the first element. Returns null if the list is empty or doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_rpop
tools.description: Pop and return a value from the right (tail) of a list. Removes and returns the last element. Returns null if the list is empty or doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_lset
tools.description: Set an element in a list at a specific index. The index must be within the list bounds or an error is returned. Use this to update specific elements without rebuilding the entire list.

tools.name: database_smembers
tools.description: Get all members of a set. Sets contain unique values - great for tags, categories, or unique identifiers.

tools.name: database_sismember
tools.description: Check if a member exists in a set. Returns true if the member is in the set, false otherwise. Use this to check membership before adding, or to verify tags/permissions.

tools.name: database_scard
tools.description: Get the number of members in a set using SCARD command.

tools.name: database_sadd
tools.description: Add members to a set. Creates the set if it doesn't exist. Sets store unique values - duplicates are automatically ignored. Returns the number of members actually added.

tools.name: database_srem
tools.description: Remove members from a set. Returns the number of members that were actually removed. Use this to untag items, remove categories, or delete specific values from a set.

tools.name: database_zrange
tools.summary: Get sorted set range (low to high)
tools.description: Get a range of members from a sorted set ordered from lowest to highest score. Perfect for leaderboards, rankings, and any scored/sorted data.

tools.name: database_zrevrange
tools.summary: Get sorted set range (high to low)
tools.description: Get a range of members from a sorted set in reverse order, highest to lowest score. Perfect for leaderboards where you want the top scorers first.

tools.name: database_zrange_withscores
tools.summary: Get sorted set range with scores (low to high)
tools.description: Get a range of members with their scores from a sorted set, ordered from lowest to highest. Use when you need both the member and its score.

tools.name: database_zrevrange_withscores
tools.summary: Get sorted set range with scores (high to low)
tools.description: Get a range of members with their scores in reverse order, highest to lowest. Perfect for leaderboards showing top players with their points.

tools.name: database_zrangebyscore
tools.description: Get members from a sorted set within a score range. Use '-inf' for negative infinity and '+inf' for positive infinity. Use this to query time ranges, price ranges, or any score-based filtering.

tools.name: database_zscore
tools.description: Get the score of a member in a sorted set. Returns null if the member doesn't exist. Use this to look up a player's score, check priority levels, or get timestamps.

tools.name: database_zrank
tools.description: Get the rank (position) of a member in a sorted set. Rank is 0-based with the lowest score at rank 0. Returns null if the member doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_zrevrank
tools.description: Get the reverse rank (position from highest score) of a member. Rank is 0-based with the highest score at rank 0. Use this for leaderboards where higher scores are better.

tools.name: database_zcard
tools.description: Get the number of members in a sorted set using ZCARD command.

tools.name: database_zadd
tools.description: Add members with scores to a sorted set. Creates the sorted set if it doesn't exist. If a member already exists, its score is updated. Use for leaderboards, priority queues, or time-series data.

tools.name: database_zrem
tools.description: Remove members from a sorted set. Returns the number of members that were actually removed. Use this to remove players from leaderboards or delete scheduled tasks.

tools.name: database_zincrby
tools.description: Increment a member's score in a sorted set. Creates the member if it doesn't exist. Returns the new score. Use negative increment to decrement. Perfect for updating leaderboard scores.

tools.name: database_execute
tools.description: Execute any Redis command including JSON.GET, JSON.SET, and other module commands. Supports Redis Stack modules. Use for commands not covered by specific tools.

tools.name: database_slowlog
tools.description: Get recent slow log entries using SLOWLOG GET command. Shows queries that exceeded the configured slowlog threshold.

tools.name: database_slowlog_len
tools.description: Get the number of entries in the slow log.

tools.name: database_client_list
tools.description: Get list of connected clients using CLIENT LIST command. Shows all active connections to the Redis server.

tools.name: database_config_get
tools.description: Get Redis configuration values matching a pattern using CONFIG GET command. Use '*' for all settings.

tools.name: database_module_list
tools.description: List all loaded Redis modules using MODULE LIST command. Shows Redis Stack modules like RedisJSON, RediSearch, etc.

tools.name: database_ft_search
tools.description: Execute a full-text search query against a RediSearch index. Supports filters, sorting, pagination, highlighting, and scoring. Use FT.SEARCH to find documents matching a query.

tools.name: database_ft_aggregate
tools.description: Perform complex aggregations on a RediSearch index including grouping, sorting, transformations, and reductions. Powerful for analytics and reporting on indexed data.

tools.name: database_ft_info
tools.description: Get detailed information about a RediSearch index including schema, document count, indexing status, memory usage, and configuration.

tools.name: database_ft_list
tools.description: List all RediSearch indexes in the database. Returns index names only - use FT.INFO for detailed information about each index.

tools.name: database_json_get
tools.description: Retrieve JSON data from a key at one or more JSONPath locations. Supports JSONPath syntax like '$.store.book[0].title' or '$..price' for recursive queries.

tools.name: database_json_set
tools.description: Create or update JSON data at a specific path. Supports NX (only if not exists) and XX (only if exists) modifiers. Path '$' sets the root document.

tools.name: database_json_del
tools.description: Remove JSON data at the specified path. Returns the number of paths deleted. If path is omitted, deletes the entire key.

tools.name: database_json_type
tools.summary: Get JSON value type at path
tools.description: Get the type of JSON value at a path: object, array, string, integer, number, boolean, or null. Useful for introspecting JSON structure.

tools.name: database_json_arrappend
tools.description: Add one or more JSON values to the end of an array at the specified path. Returns the new array length.

tools.name: database_json_arrlen
tools.description: Get the number of elements in a JSON array at the specified path. Returns null if the path doesn't exist or isn't an array.

tools.name: database_json_numincrby
tools.description: Atomically increment a number at the specified JSON path. Use negative values to decrement. Returns the new value.

tools.name: database_json_strlen
tools.description: Get the length of a JSON string at the specified path. Returns null if the path doesn't exist or isn't a string.

tools.name: database_ts_add
tools.description: Append a timestamp-value pair to a time series. Use '*' for auto-generated timestamp. Supports retention, encoding, chunk size, duplicate policy, and labels. Creates the key if needed.

tools.name: database_ts_get
tools.description: Get the most recent timestamp-value pair from a time series. Useful for getting current readings from sensors, metrics, or IoT devices.

tools.name: database_ts_range
tools.description: Query samples from a time series between two timestamps. Supports filtering, counting, alignment, and aggregation (avg, sum, min, max, count, first, last, range, std.p, std.s, var.p, var.s).

tools.name: database_ts_info
tools.description: Get metadata about a time series including retention, chunk count, memory usage, first/last timestamps, labels, and compaction rules.

tools.name: database_ts_create
tools.description: Create an empty time series with optional retention, encoding, chunk size, duplicate policy, and labels. Use this to pre-configure a time series before adding samples.

tools.name: database_bf_reserve
tools.description: Initialize a Bloom filter with specified error rate and capacity. Use expansion for auto-scaling or nonscaling to fix size. Lower error rate = more memory but fewer false positives.

tools.name: database_bf_add
tools.description: Add a single item to a Bloom filter. Returns true if newly added, false if it may have existed. Creates the filter with defaults if it doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_bf_madd
tools.summary: Add multiple items to Bloom filter
tools.description: Add multiple items to a Bloom filter in a single operation. More efficient than multiple BF.ADD calls. Returns array of booleans for each item.

tools.name: database_bf_exists
tools.summary: Check if item exists in Bloom filter
tools.description: Check if an item may exist in a Bloom filter. Returns true if the item may exist (with false positive probability), false if it definitely doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_bf_mexists
tools.summary: Check multiple items in Bloom filter
tools.description: Check if multiple items exist in a Bloom filter in a single operation. More efficient than multiple BF.EXISTS calls. Returns array of booleans.

tools.name: database_bf_info
tools.description: Get metadata about a Bloom filter including capacity, size, number of filters, items inserted, and expansion rate. Useful for monitoring filter health.

tools.name: database_xadd
tools.description: Append an entry to a stream with field-value pairs. Use '*' for auto-generated ID. Supports MAXLEN for capped streams. Creates the stream if it doesn't exist. Use for event sourcing, message queues, and activity logs.

tools.name: database_xread
tools.description: Read entries from one or more streams. Use '$' to read only new entries, or specific IDs to read from a position. Supports blocking with timeout. Use for consuming events without consumer groups.

tools.name: database_xrange
tools.summary: Get stream entries by ID range
tools.description: Get entries from a stream between two IDs. Use '-' for minimum ID and '+' for maximum ID. Supports COUNT to limit results. Perfect for reading stream history or replaying events.

tools.name: database_xrevrange
tools.summary: Get stream entries in reverse order
tools.description: Get entries from a stream in reverse order (newest first). Use '+' for maximum ID and '-' for minimum ID. Perfect for getting the most recent entries.

tools.name: database_xlen
tools.description: Get the number of entries in a stream. Use to monitor stream size and growth.

tools.name: database_xinfo_stream
tools.description: Get detailed information about a stream including length, radix tree stats, first/last entry, and consumer groups. Use 'full' option for complete details including all entries and consumers.

tools.name: database_xinfo_groups
tools.description: Get information about all consumer groups for a stream including name, consumers count, pending entries, and last delivered ID.

tools.name: database_xinfo_consumers
tools.description: Get information about all consumers in a consumer group including name, pending count, and idle time.

tools.name: database_xgroup_create
tools.description: Create a new consumer group for a stream. Use '$' to only receive new messages, '0' to receive all messages, or specific ID. Use MKSTREAM to create stream if it doesn't exist.

tools.name: database_xgroup_destroy
tools.description: Delete a consumer group from a stream. All pending entries and consumers are removed. Returns 1 if successful, 0 if group didn't exist.

tools.name: database_xgroup_delconsumer
tools.description: Remove a consumer from a consumer group. Returns the number of pending messages that were owned by the consumer. The pending entries become unassigned.

tools.name: database_xgroup_setid
tools.description: Set the last delivered ID for a consumer group. Use to reprocess messages or skip ahead. Use '$' for latest, '0' for beginning.

tools.name: database_xreadgroup
tools.summary: Read stream entries as consumer group
tools.description: Read entries from streams as a consumer in a consumer group. Use '>' for new messages never delivered to any consumer, or specific ID for pending entries. Supports blocking and NOACK for fire-and-forget.

tools.name: database_xack
tools.description: Acknowledge one or more stream entries as processed by a consumer group. Removes entries from the pending entries list. Returns the number of entries acknowledged.

tools.name: database_xdel
tools.description: Delete one or more entries from a stream by ID. Returns the number of entries actually deleted. Note: entries in pending lists may still reference deleted IDs.

tools.name: database_xtrim
tools.description: Trim a stream to approximately (with ~) or exactly the specified maximum length. Removes oldest entries first. Use for capped streams to limit memory usage.

tools.name: database_xpending
tools.description: Get information about pending entries in a consumer group - entries delivered but not yet acknowledged. Can filter by consumer, ID range, and count. Essential for monitoring message processing.

tools.name: database_xclaim
tools.description: Transfer ownership of pending entries to a different consumer. Use min-idle-time to only claim entries idle for at least that many milliseconds. Useful for handling consumer failures.

tools.name: database_xautoclaim
tools.description: Scan and claim pending entries that have been idle for at least min-idle-time milliseconds. Combines XPENDING and XCLAIM into one command. Returns claimed entries and cursor for next scan.

tools.name: database_publish
tools.description: Publish a message to a Pub/Sub channel. Returns the number of subscribers that received the message. Messages are fire-and-forget - not stored. Use for real-time notifications and broadcasting.

tools.name: database_pubsub_channels
tools.description: List active Pub/Sub channels with at least one subscriber. Optionally filter by glob pattern. Use to discover what channels are currently in use.

tools.name: database_pubsub_numsub
tools.description: Get the number of subscribers for specified channels. Returns channel-count pairs. Use to monitor channel activity and subscriber distribution.

tools.name: database_pubsub_numpat
tools.description: Get the number of pattern subscriptions (PSUBSCRIBE). Returns the total count of unique patterns being subscribed to across all clients.
